discourse_list.title: INFORMAL POLL: Should MakerDAO RWA establish a free speech trust (Delaware) for the benefit of Web3 and Twitter Users, to Finance Elon Musk\xe2\x80\x99s Purchase of and Open Sourcing of Twitter?

content.content: Summary:  Twitter has underperformed the S&P 500 since 2013 by % (you would have made a fortune on longing S&P and shorting Twitter) Elon Musk is, newly, the largest shareholder of Twitter, inc. at nearly 10% If from 2013 to today you’d longed Musk’s Tesla and shorted Twitter that spread trade would have made you % (an even bigger fortune) On April 13th, 2022, Musk made a tender offer at $54.20 per share ($43B) to take Twitter private Musk’s stated goal is to open source Twitter for the purpose of safeguarding free speech For that, we propose on-chain governance for Twitter Twitter is the town square of Web3 and many other communities This signal request asks: Should Web3 and MakerDAO consider providing debt financing to Musk for such a leveraged buy-out? If so, what terms should Web3 demand as a lender? [remember the golden rule: He who has the gold makes the rules.] Below are the facts, why this matters, and proposed terms for a hypothetical debt facility with $500M in anchor funding from MakerDAO (super-senior secured and with Musk’s personal guarantee) and the Delaware statutory trust for Web3 to effectively acquire Twitter so that an open source Twitter protocol can emerge. The alternatives:  Elon acquires Twitter but fails to do a Web3 integration Twitter fends off his bid, remains independent, and continues to languish at the center of the culture war Another acquirer emerges: Google, Disney, Comcast, or a Saudi Prince who likes to dismember journalists for speech he doesn’t like   We are in a culture war between centralized elitists who don’t believe in free speech (feel threatened by free speech) and decentralized populists who want to retain our First Amendment rights   Informal Poll:    Should MakerDAO establish a free speech trust (Delaware) for the benefit of Web3 and Twitter Users, to Finance Elon Musk’s Purchase of and Open Sourcing of Twitter?  YES work on a MIP for debt financing Musk and Web3 open sourcing Twitter, inc. as Twitter protocol, a public good for messaging/communication YES work on a MIP and I am willing to co-author it or co-sponsor it NO, STOP THIS NONSENSE     0 voters      Musk’s Offer on April 13th, 2022: “Bret Taylor Chairman of the Board, I invested in Twitter as I believe in its potential to be the platform for free speech around the globe, and I believe free speech is a societal imperative for a functioning democracy. However, since making my investment I now realize the company will neither thrive nor serve this societal imperative in its current form. Twitter needs to be transformed as a private company. As a result, I am offering to buy 100% of Twitter for $54.20 per share in cash, a 54% premium over the day before I began investing in Twitter and a 38% premium over the day before my investment was publicly announced. My offer is my best and final offer and if it is not accepted, I would need to reconsider my position as a shareholder. Twitter has extraordinary potential. I will unlock it. /s/ Elon Musk”  Facts:  Twitter is an iconic asset; it is the town square of Web3 and many other communities Twitter is inundated with spam and bots It is struggling with how to safeguard freedom of speech The assets of the company are woefully underexploited and mismanaged The current share price is roughly the same as it was in 2013 (while SPY has gone up and to the right violently, Twitter has not). Twitter could be used to onboard millions of users to Web3 via the adoption of a governance token with on chain governance and by integrating crypto wallets for user authentication Musk has the resources to acquire Twitter and demonstrably Musk is a champion of free speech Musk has a track record of building best in class products and growing his companies exponentially Musk has a track record of actually open sourcing valuable IP such as Tesla patents Musk asserts that “I don’t care about the economics at all.” implying that Musk would be amenable to capped upside for him, with excess value accruing to the users of Twitter (the “Twitter Community”)   Technical Implementation:  MakerDAO’s portion of funds can come into the real world by the creation of a new vault with $500M debt ceiling and a MIP21 secure conduit to the Delaware statutory trust (using a licensed broker-dealer intermediary for the swap of Dai to USD)   RWA Legal Structure:  A Delaware statutory trust for the benefit of Web3 and Twitter users A “Free Speech Trust” as a vehicle specially designed to support open sourcing most of Twitter and safeguarding our first amendment right to freedom of speech   Lender Participants:  MakerDAO as an anchor $500M of super-senior secured debt Other DeFi lending protocols like AAVE, Compound, Uniswap, etc. if these protocols are so inclined to be lenders (they have enormous unused treasuries) Other Qualified Purchasers Others, as possible in compliance with the law, who want to lend to Musk and govern a Twitter Protocol   Proposed Terms of Debt:  Senior secured debt cross collateralized by a personal guarantee from Musk 25 bps over 30 day SOFR Governance: Musk to vote his % of ownership but a maximum of 10%, with participants in this Delaware trust and Twitter users to vote the other 90% in on-chain governance Open source terms: All code that can be open sourced without violating user privacy must be open sourced, with on chain governance Crypto wallets (e.g. Metamask) must be integrated for user authentication Musk to be capped out at profiting beyond a Twitter having a valuation of $69.420B, with the remainder of Musk’s future profits distributed (e.g. airdropped) to Twitter’s human users   Open Sourcing Twitter and Launching Twitter Protocol on Web3. Ideas:  All algorithms posted to GitHub Everything that can be published to GitHub under the law should be Make it know what code is being run in production Give a community of governance token holders the ability to make changes to the code being run using on chain governance Governance by tweet? Progressively migrating servers to Web3 Allowing users to export their social graph and Tweets Giving user’s ownership of each of their Tweets as an NFT Labeling users as human or bot Sybil resistance Gas charges to reduce spam Metamask integration as login with an NFT for each account Multi-chain integration including Arweave integration   What’s at stake: Free Speech  Our First Amendment rights are at stake   Investment Bankers for Musk:  Musk has engaged Morgan Stanley as financial advisor.   What we should expect from Musk:  From time to time, Musk may engage in discussions with the Board and/or members of the Issuer’s management team concerning, including, without limitation, the Proposal, potential business combinations and strategic alternatives, the business, operations, capital structure, governance, management, strategy of the Issuer and other matters concerning the Issuer. Musk may express his views to the Board and/or members of the Issuer’s management team and/or the public through social media or other channels with respect to the Issuer’s business, products and service offerings.   Regulatory & Reporting:  If Musk’s Proposed Transaction is completed, the Common Stock would become eligible for termination of its registration pursuant to Section 12(g)(4) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended, and would be delisted from the New York Stock Exchange. Web3 requires that Musk keep the same reporting standards as a public company, to the extent doing so does not hinder the ability to open source Twitter as a communications protocol public good under the stewardship of the American people   Why take Twitter private, and wen token(s)?  “Twitter needs to be transformed as a private company.” - Elon Musk The advantages to going private are less regulatory overhead, and so on… The pitfalls are… (?) The plan: use six months as a private company to consider token(s), economic design/mechanism, copyleft vs. copyright, stewardship of this digital town square and communications protocol public good, and how we get the Federal Government of the USA seeing this phenomenal opportunity to again lead the free world Goal of aligning shareholders interests with that of the network user   Big Hairy Audacious Goals:  Launch a minimum viable protocol for governing on chain in two weeks or less   Musk’s Tender Offer Proposal is non-binding  and, once structured and agreed upon, would be conditioned upon, among other things, the  (i) receipt of any required governmental approvals; (ii) confirmatory legal, business, regulatory, accounting and tax due diligence; (iii) the negotiation and execution of definitive agreements providing for the Proposed Transaction; and (iv) completion of anticipated financing   Next Step if signal passes?   @maxglass will lead the drafting of a MIP6 real world asset onboarding. The collateral shall be held in a Delaware statutory trust or other vehicle best suited to steward this public good protocol until it is sufficiently decentralized (see Nakamoto Coefficient by @balajis)   TwitterDAO Anthem, a cover of ENS DAO Song A Day:  ENS DAO cover song   Sources:   The SEC filing of Musk’s ownership: 9.2% or 73,486,938 shares of Common Stock out of 800,641,166 shares outstanding as of February 10, 2022 Musk’s tender offer SEC filing Elon at TED 2022 Analysis: The All-In podcast episode 76  A sampling of the scary reactions from media and intellectuals that are pro-totalitarianism and anti free speech:  https://twitter.com/jeffjarvis/status/1514578609754812419 https://twitter.com/maxboot/status/1514570168730636290 https://twitter.com/DefiantLs/status/1514738236207337477 https://twitter.com/auronmacintyre/status/1514653963408318474   Glenn Greenwald  “They have somehow inverted history so that they now believe that it is not censorship that is the favored tool of fascists, tyrants, and authoritarians – even though every fascist and despot in history used censorship as a key means for maintaining power – but instead believe that it is free speech, free discourse, and free thought that are the instruments of repression.”       Excerpts of Transcript of Musk at TED 2022  Elon from 11:26 it’s very important for there to be an inclusive arena for free speech where— Twitter has become kind of the de facto town square. So it’s just really important that people have both the reality and the perception that they are able to speak freely within the bounds of the law. So one of the things that I believe Twitter should do is open source the algorithm and make any changes to people’s tweets, if they’re emphasized or de-emphasized, that action should be made apparent so anyone can see that action’s been taken so there’s no behind the scenes manipulation, either algorithmically or manually. I think everyone will still blame me for everything. Yeah. If I acquire Twitter and something goes wrong, it’s my fault. A hundred percent. I just think it’s important to the function of democracy. It’s important to the function of the United States as a free country and many other countries and to actually help freedom in the world and more importantly in the US. And so I think the civilizational risk is decreased the more we can increase the trust of Twitter as a public platform. the intent… it’s definitely not from the standpoint of let me figure out how to monopolize or maximize my ownership of Twitter, what I’m saying is this is not a way to make money. It’s just that my strong, intuitive sense is that having a public platform that is maximally trusted and broadly inclusive is extremely important to the future of civilization. I don’t care about the economics at all. In my view Twitter should match the laws of the country and really there’s an obligation to do that. But going beyond that and having it be unclear who’s making what changes to where, having tweets mysteriously be promoted and demoted with no insight into what’s going on, having a black box algorithm promote some things and not other things, I think this can be quite dangerous. the code should be on GitHub. You know? So then, can look through it, and say, “I see a problem here. I don’t agree with this.” They can highlight issues, suggest changes, in the same way that you update Linux or Signal or something like that. I do think that we want to be just very reluctant to delete things, just be very cautious with permanent bans. Timeouts I think are better than permanent bans. I think we want it to really have the perception and reality that speech is as free as reasonably possible. And a good sign as to whether there is free speech is if someone you don’t like allowed to say something you don’t like. And if that is the case, then we have free speech. And it’s damn annoying when someone you don’t like says something you don’t like. That is a sign of a healthy, functioning free speech situation. I think it’s very important that the algorithm be open sourced and that any manual adjustments be identified. So if somebody did something to a tweet, there’s information attached to it that that action was taken. And I wouldn’t personally be in there editing tweets. But you’ll know if something was done to promote, demote, or otherwise affect a tweet. As for media ownership, a share ownership structure that will have Mark Zuckerberg the 14th still controlling those entities… We won’t have that at Twitter. a top priority I would have is eliminating the spam and scam bots and the bot armies that are on Twitter. They make the product much worse. If I had a Dogecoin for every crypto scam I saw, I would have a hundred billion Dogecoin. I think you’d only have the edit capability for a short period of time. And probably the thing to do upon the edit would be to zero out all retweets and favorites. I’m open to ideas, though. I’m literally on the toilet or something like, “Ha-ha, this is funny.” And then tweet that out. That’s like most of them. Sure, I don’t like to lose. I’m not sure many people do, but truth matters to me a lot, really. Pathologically, it matters to me. The obsession with truth is why I studied physics, because physics attempts to understand the truth of the universe. Physics, it’s just what are the provable truths of the universe and truths that have predictive power. You make a triangle with 42 degrees and two 69s. There’s no such thing as a perfect triangle. Or is there? Yeah. I have a proposal for a worldview or a motivating philosophy, which is to understand what questions to ask about the answer that is the universe and to agree that we expand the scope and scale of consciousness, biological and digital, we will be better able to ask these questions, to frame these questions and to understand why we’re here, how we got here, what the heck is going on. That is my driving philosophy, is to expand the scope and scale of consciousness, that we may better understand the nature of the universe. I think we want to obviously do our absolute best to ensure that the future is good for everyone’s children, and that the future is something that you can look forward to and not feel sad about. You want to get up in the morning and be excited about the future, and we should fight for the things that make us excited about the future. There’s got to be things that get you excited like you want to live. I love humanity and I think that we should fight for a good future for humanity. I think we should be optimistic about the future and fight to make that optimistic future happen.  Excerpts of Analysis from David Sachs on the All-In Podcast Episode 76.0: David Sachs: we have to look at the track record of this management team, which it barely exists, but also this culture at Twitter. This is a company that’s languished for years, a decade. This culture has been so inept that in response to Elon’s takeover offer they gave all the employees a day of rest. The employees were so stressed out they told them to stay at home and take it easy. This team is weak, soft, and Elon would give the whole company an enima and fix this thing, and that is why they don’t want him taking over. That is why you should not let this board and this CEO invoke some magical plan that they don’t have, that they never came up with because it’s just a big excuse so they’re not out of a job. What is this story really about? It’s about free speech. He said this is not about economics for me. Twitter needs to be the open town square, it is the marketplace of ideas. We’re going to make it a free speech platform. We are going to open source the algorithm so people know when they’re being canceled they know why they were taken down. Is that algorithmic, was that a human intervention? This is what it’s about for you all. This is also what it’s about for all the elites, for everyone observing it, criticizing it. Look at the reactions the hysterical reactions. Business insider “Elon Musk’s attempt to buy Twitter represents a chilling new threat: billionaire trolls taking over social media.” so these guys are completely hypocritical Jeff Jarvis Tweet https://twitter.com/jeffjarvis/status/1514578609754812419 Somehow these people think that the reinstitution, the restoration of free speech is somehow like the end of Weimar Germany. Max Boot Tweet https://twitter.com/maxboot/status/1514570168730636290 In the warped mind of these elites and the corporate media, they think that for democracy to survive they need more censorship. Chamath: Objective fact: Twitter has the same stock price while the rest of the S&P has gone absolutely up and to the right in a violent manner. Whatever has happened here inside this business has not been working for nearly a decade. Devil I don’t know will be better than the devil I do know. Sachs: Play for a bigger bid… run an auction… No principal agent problem in that context (decentralized) Put it to a vote and let every single shareholder decide Limits on ability for Elon going on the market and buying more Friedberg: Really important from corporate governance Job of board is to look out for interest of shareholders particularly minority shareholders Is there upside for the smaller shareholders Chamath What also works Do the right thing Get a fairness opinion Goldman is probably doing it as we speak When you factor in the market beta today Path to a bigger outcome? Board will have of justifying the alternative of not taking this Alot of shareholders want to get out. Vanguard has to own through these ETFs How many concerned interested shareholders are there Friedberg What about Jack who owns 2% Jack is on the board Jason: Twitter 2021 $5B, 8,000 employees $625K per employee Google: 135,000 employees, 257B, $2M per employee Sach Refuses to be CEO saying “I’m a VC now. C’mon. I’m done operating companies. I’m sick of it. I don’t like doing real work. I’m too old.” Chamath: Had previously tried to takeover and do David as CEO Sachs: Startups are like the NBA I’m retired. I’m the coach. Sachs: On the ground. Plug in there. Project Manager or Product Manager A deep bench Elon is the new GE Jason: AI team on self driving If he took one person They’d solve the bot problem the spam problem in 3 days Sachs: He’d get rid of the bots The sight would be cleaner It’s also an ideological battle or struggle The big struggle of our time is populist vs. elitist Elon is one of the rare billionaires that’s anti-elitist Somehow the elites are in favor of censorship To protect their control over democracy They’re greatly outnumbered The more democratic this county becomes The more they are going to lose power and be kicked out So fiercely resisting the restoration of Twitter as a free speech platform It means the end of their cultural power Chamath: Tweet that encapsulates it to a T @axios tweet: The world’s richest man – someone who used to be compared to Marvel’s Iron Man – is increasingly behaving like a movie supervillian, commanding seemingly unlimited resources with which to finance his mischief-making. Are you serious? Jason: That’s journalism? Chamath: This is the same guy doing more on climate change, and has been doing it for 20 years before it was popular, and satellites, and space travel, and I think if he does get a control of Twitter and there is a strong reliable moral force for free speech then that will be his greatest contribution to society. We want this political philosophy of democracy and capitalism to roughly work together and I think it sits on top of this fundamental idea that you can say what you think without fear of retribution and it’s only there that you can seek out different opinions and … without such a high cost for making mistakes. Jason: Elon Musk spends a significant portion of his fortune to restore trust in public square by open sourcing the API and allowing transparent moderation That’s what he said in his Ted Talk Sachs: Look at the hysterical reactions A supervillian in their eyes because he will give right to free speech back. Today the press doesn’t believe in free speech Greenwald excerpt: They have somehow inverted history so now they believe it is not censorship tha is the favored tool of despot … free speed, free discourse, that are the instruments of oppression. Their cultural power. Predictions: 30 days from now, what is your majority case, what happens? Sachs: Elon thwarted Corporate media, political elites, and the board Either the poison pill will win and stock will be in the dumps and the board members sued Or they find a buyer for Twitter another buyer at the same or greater price and in the hands of another company who they regard as safer because that company is bought into the regime of censorship Google? Comcast? Lina Kahn We will find out how rigged and how deep the corruption goes! Friedberg: Board of rational actors… High integrity Wants to see Elon get it. A rational view on moderation. He’d be excited for Elon It’ll be a multi-month process and Elon will go do something else Chamath: 30 days to 90 days from now Nobody wants to buy this dumpster fire Corporate boards and companies and CEOs don’t have the stomach for that First they’ll reject it (not in the fiduciary best interest of shareholders) as a sign of ego not logic. By saying it, look, whenever there’s a merger announced Merger Arbitrage. Alot of people believe the board is not going to do the right thing Sachs: The fix is in Chamath: The money good thing to do is to buy that equity to bleed into the acquisition price. The board is going to reject the offer.  Episode 2: Sachs: intellectually confident, don’t believe in shutting down the debate. Lost the art of persuasion. " Jason: "They’ve given up trying to reach…”
This is too compelling not to dedicate more effort to this endeavor. Private equity wants nothing to do with Twitter. I would vote yes, but I’m too new here.
voted no, because: focus focus focus. outside of the US nobody cares if twitter is public or owned by elon. we got bigger fish to fry ;p

Seems like he could buy it without financing if he really wanted to. Plus, without the consent and participation of the Musk team, I’m not sure how this would even work. Maybe I am missing something but isn’t this putting the cart before the horse ?

$500 Million DAI loan?  that could be a big enough loan to bring down Maker as we have < $70MM in capital surplus. Do you think DAI holders want Maker to invest its liquid funds (which back the DAI) in large scale, arguably risky endeavors like this?   If this would be a super secure loan, please present the case… UPDATE:  where did these proposed terms come from? Is Elon even willing to give a personal guarantee on the proposed loan, for example? How do you view the collateral package backing the proposed loan? Any idea where Elon plans to get the other ~$43B of funding needed for his proposed acquisition?  That is a significant amount of capital and whoever provides a big share of the that capital will likely be driving the terms of the deal, not a $500MM funder   MakerDAO as an anchor $500M of super-senior secured debt Other DeFi lending protocols like AAVE, Compound, Uniswap, etc. if these protocols are so inclined to be lenders (they have enormous unused treasuries) Other Qualified Purchasers Others, as possible in compliance with the law, who want to lend to Musk and govern a Twitter Protocol   Proposed Terms of Debt:  Senior secured debt cross collateralized by a personal guarantee from Musk 25 bps over 30 day SOFR Governance: Musk to vote his % of ownership but a maximum of 10%, with participants in this Delaware trust and Twitter users to vote the other 90% in on-chain governance Open source terms: All code that can be open sourced without violating user privacy must be open sourced, with on chain governance Crypto wallets (e.g. Metamask) must be integrated for user authentication Musk to be capped out at profiting beyond a Twitter having a valuation of $69.420B, with the remainder of Musk’s future profits distributed (e.g. airdropped) to Twitter’s human users
I’m not sure “bring down Maker” is warranted – it would be an extremely bad event to lose that much DAI but it’s still one Maker could recover from in various ways.

OK - I updated it to say could bring down Maker. The point remains - this is a large proposed loan much bigger than Maker’s surplus and a loss on this order of magnitude would present a serious risk to Maker - which may or may not recover…
I should add: this was a reply to your wording only. The proposal itself is a terrible idea.

Thank you for voting and replying. The NO votes dominate, so I’ll crumple this idea up and toss it into the trash bin.     Eumenes:  where did these proposed terms come from?   The terms came from me alone, ideating, and I put this poll forward personally, not on behalf of RWA Co. Thanks again.
Aw, don’t take it too hard on yourself. The Maker community should be open to all ideas and discussions. So thank you for the idea.

No problem. Its an interesting idea. I didnt vote as I wanted to know more before deciding. There could be something interesting there but i think you would want to discuss interest with Elon’s team first and also see if there is a low risk way for Maker to participate. I wouldnt assume Elon would be willing to give a PG…

Agreed. Nobody should be afraid to share ideas. That is how we all will learn and build. I think the intent behind this idea is wonderful and I appreciate that you took the time to put this together @maxglass

Ya I don’t know why the community wouldn’t consider ideating on this further. Even if it was merely for a portion of the acquisition, it could be interesting. I think this was an out of the box idea that was shot down too quickly. I see a mix of great questions here along with a few closed minded opinions. Bummer.
I concur. There are some good ideas here in general.  But if someone has a connection to Elon he can be advised that Maker is ready for him should he need it.  You never know…
Not in the US but I do care   I also thinks it helps an organization like MakerDAO focus on the greater mission.

Maybe there is a way for Maker to connect with someone on Elon’s team and let him know Maker is interested in financing some low risk part of his various projects? The DeFi vision would likely resonate with him…

If the acquisition is real and not a stunt, which as of yesterday was seeming like it was from the media that came across my screen, the next step in moving the tender offer further along, would be for Elon to present the way in which it would be financed.

The first question would be if Elon actually wants to borrow money from us. I think it would be great  for the DAO to do. The PR alone would be massive and he is a fairly reliable debtor. However, its a waste of resources until he gives some indication that he wants us to give him a loan.

Update - looks like Musk already has “funding secured”:    Reuters – 21 Apr 22    Musk says he has secured $46.5 bln in funding for Twitter bid Elon Musk on Thursday said he has lined up $46.5 billion in debt and equity financing to buy Twitter Inc and is considering taking his offer directly to shareholders, a filing with U.S. regulators showed.
He just isn’t ready yet. That’s ok, the time will come.
yesterday I launched 69420 DAO to get Musk to integrate Web3 into Twitter. Please join if you’re so inclined. We will have an NFT with some dope art.

Looks like the acquisition is going forward,   CNN – 25 Apr 22    Elon Musk to buy Twitter in $44 billion deal | CNN Business Twitter has agreed to sell itself to Elon Musk in a deal valued at around $44 billion, the company said Monday.
Yea, I’m kinda surprised. I didn’t think it was going to happen. This is really a major development.
I wonder how Elon is financing the $44B…

I think there are some details circulating online. I was reading something that said the financing was very attractive to the shareholders and they gave the board pushback. It looked like Elon was going full scale hostile takeover but they worked it out. The guy who, not so long ago (like a few weeks), was tweeting about whether Twitter should remove the “w” from Twitter just bought Twitter. This should be interesting!

Matt Levine did a good writeup of the financing. The short version is he is using a variety of debt and equity commitments, with hope that other investors will go in with him so he doesn’t have to finance the entire 44 billion. https://newsletterhunt.com/emails/20984
Yes, this a a good write up. Thanks for providing this link.
This topic was automatically closed 30 days after the last reply. New replies are no longer allowed.
